bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, May 27, 1941

div1.p: Andrus informs Hench that his manuscript, which detailed his role in the yellow fever experiments, was rejected by Hearst publications.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, May 27, 1941
div1.opener:
J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
May
27th.
1941.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Am enclosing the photograph of myself for you
to have copied. This is the one for which
search was being made when you were here.

I had yellow fever in Feb. 1901. This photo
was taken in March or April of the same year
when I was home on furlough...

The manuscript of my story was returned by the
Hearst publications with one of those cute re-
jection slips we read about in stories about
struggling young authors.

I shall not thrust my brain child out into the
cruel world again until after I receive your
criticism. (Probably not even then.)

In a previous letter you delicately suggested
that “editors might want to change it around”.
From this I deduce that you found plenty wrong...

Had an invitation, today, to the unveiling of
Dean Cornwell's Conquerors of Yellow Fever and
note that you are to be among the honor guests...
Please give my regards to Kissinger and Kellogg.

Am looking forward to seeing a print of this painting
with a great deal of interest...

Bye-the-way: I intend, after I receive your
criticism of my story, to write my small part
in the experiments for your use. In other
words, I shall assume that your book will tell
the complete story of the work of Major Reed's
Board so that what I write for you will cover
only my tiny part.
